home.body:

  • Week 1
  • Week 2
  • Week 3
  • Week 4
  • Week 5
  • Week 6

Welcome to Computer Science Essentials PE

Please begin this module by reviewing the module handbook. You will find additional information such as the weekly schedule, learning methods, and essential resources. Students are responsible for reading the content of this document. For further information, contact your instructor

View module handbook

Module Outline

This course is an introduction and foundation for students about to study Computer Science at British University Vietnam. It ensures that students have all the required skills, abilities and knowledge required to succeed at studying Computer Science at an undergraduate level.

This course has three modules: Programming Essentials (40%25), Networking and Web Principles (30%25) and Technical Communication (30%25)

Learning Outcomes

By the end of this module, you will be able to:

.

Students will be able to understand the founding principles of computer programming and write simple code.

.

Students will be able to understand simple networking layouts and create simple networks.

.

Students will be able to communicate the knowledge that they have learned.

Assessments

  • Assessment 1 - Programming Essentials: Individual Portfolio (40%25)

  • Assessment 2 - Networking and Web Principles: Weekly class quizzes and tasks (30%25)

  • Assessment 3 - Technical Communications: Weekly Group work assessments (30%25)

Assessment dates

Please note and manage your submission dates, they are important, and you must submit your assessments before the deadline. It is NOT possible to request an extension. The University will NOT send reminders if your submission is late or if you do not submit at all. If there are exceptional circumstances outside your control (for example, serious illness) affecting your ability to submit on time, you can download an Exceptional Circumstances (EC) formLinks to an external site..

Module Leader

.

Module Leader: Fraser Harrison

Fraser Harrison

Fraser completed a Software Engineering degree (Bachelor of Engineering with Honours) from Edinburgh Napier University in 2013 with a primary focus on machine learning and genetic algorithms. In 2016, he moved to Vietnam and worked for the British Embassy, managing their IT infrastructure, before moving to a cyber-security related role. In 2020, he returned to academia, completing a Master of Software Engineering focusing on “progressive web” applications. Fraser is currently working on various research projects relating computer science and computational thinking.

Contact

Email: fraser.h@buv.edu.vn

week2.body:
Welcome to week 2

This week we will look at ...... By the end of this lesson you should be able to ....

.

LESSON CONTENT

  1. Prework: Read Part I of the course textbook. Essential features of academic writing

  2. Class 1: Lecture: After introducing ourselves, let's get started with academic integrity. We'll learn about what it is and how to avoid it, including websites to stay away from and what browsers you should use to conduct research.

  3. Class 2: Group workshop

  4. Class 3: Practical activity

  5. Class 4: Wrap up and Quiz

.

STUDY MATERIALS

  • Self-check: What is good academic conduct according to Staffordshire University?

  • Read: Find out when to paraphrase and when to summarise

  • Play: Defeat the plagiarism Goblins!

  • PPT: Review this week's lecture ppt

.

Ask questions, view comments, and get follow-up materials on the course noticeboard
